instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad clicks but nothing on screen
threads.message:
I have this board that was sent in for water damage. When I plugged it in the trackpad would click and the ammeter read 19.8v and 0.55A
The only components that looked like they had any kind of liquid damage were <CAPACITOR>C8412</CAPACITOR> , <CAPACITOR>C7660</CAPACITOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR>. I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7660</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C8412</CAPACITOR> and put the board in the ultrasonic.

Now the board is still doing the same thing except now the amps keep going up all the way until 2.49A but still nothing on the screen. 
L7670 is showing 5v

I'm not sure exactly where to start troubleshooting since the trackpad still works and gets power to it and if I measured correctly I dont think there was any voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad clicks but nothing on screen
threads.message:
Check other S3 and S0 voltages on the coils.
Now it gets 2.49A from charger w/, or w/o battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad clicks but nothing on screen
threads.message:
That was with the battery in. Wout the battery it goes to 0.05A for a couple seconds then stays at 0A.

I checked for voltages on <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and they had 0v.
L7690(<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>) has 3.3v on it and L7030

threads.message:
[QUOTE="ytesfay80, post: 71199, member: 90"]
That was with the battery in. Wout the battery it goes to 0.05A for a couple seconds then stays at 0A.

I checked for voltages on <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and they had 0v.
L7690(<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>) has 3.3v on it and L7030
[/QUOTE]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad clicks but nothing on screen
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> levels.
Mention if not present, but pulsing (if is the case).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad clicks but nothing on screen
threads.message: From what I saw there was no voltage or pulsing on neither <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad clicks but nothing on screen
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
Be sure <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> is steady high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad clicks but nothing on screen
threads.message:
I couldnt find the ONOFF lines for this board because the board view I have is on a pdf file.
I checked for voltage on <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR> and got 0v on both.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad clicks but nothing on screen
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad clicks but nothing on screen
threads.message:
I booted in DFU mode. Initially I tried to revive firmware but I never saw anything appear on the screen like I have in the past then it froze so I cancelled it and restored the firmware.

Again I didn't see anything appear on the screen then this image appeared on the screen that said booted(Image attached).

Now when I try booting in DFU mode it won't let me restore or revive it and gives the message I also linked below.

When I turn boot to an external monitor I don't get any image either.

[ATTACH type="full" alt="Screen Shot 2021-02-06 at 11.01.41 AM.png"]59675[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full" alt="Screen Shot 2021-02-06 at 11.19.33 AM.png"]59676[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad clicks but nothing on screen
threads.message:
You can try to reflash <CHIP>U4770</CHIP>, SoC ROM, with a good dump from other board.
Some people claim on Internet they solved not booting boards this way.

Is just something to try.
Make backup of the content first.
